reviews.review_msg: Take this class if it's your only class, his lectures leave you brittle like glass. Enters the room with a coke, always has his notes hidden behind a cloak. Learn to write fast, or you'll forget everything like it's in the past. Focus on his assignments, work til you need a back alignment. I passed but I still dislike his teaching like Comcast.

Tom is a strong believer that the best way to learn how something works is by implementing it. In this course, we started with a setPixel() method, and ended it with an implementation of a 3D model renderer (subset of .obj files) and a graphics specification language for composing scenes. It was a lot of work, but was well worth it.

Start project early - it's a lot of work. Project is built upon throughout the semester and applies what you learned in class. Lectures can get confusing but the application of the concepts to the project helps. Don't be afraid to ask Tom for help when you get stuck, he's really kind. Final project is pretty cool. Not OpenGL based.
Try to avoid his class, assignments and exams were hard and he curves down the marks!!!!   The most boring class and worst prof I have ever had.
This guy was significantly more competent for teaching the course.
Good prof, decent lectures and lecture notes. Overall a difficult course regardless. Most of the class did very poorly but it was graded on a curve.

Good professor. 
Yagiz makes it tough but Xue Bin balances it out well.
Assignments are a smidge tough but nothing a few hours can't solve.

This professor made up for the first part of the course (taught by Yagiz), he was an incredible professor who cared about making course content clear and understood by students. There were many examples that were directly related to the content in assignments. The assignments were fun and interesting, and the final exam was fair and relevant

I feel like he has improved a lot as i feel like the past ratings didn't really match my experience. During lecture he gave us a lot of space to ask questions and encouraged questions and answered silly questions. he gave a practice midterm and he emphaizes what you NEED to know for exam in lecture. He was also funny sometimes!made me hehehe a few

As usual for this school he is a research professor that does not actually want to teach courses. Zero care was put into explaining any of the concepts if you dont go look for yourself in the book. Zero clue what would be on the exam because he refused to say. Just remove this course or have jason teach it by himself, he is not a good teacher.
The reviews are right

WORST PROF EVER! I mean the rating speaks for itself. I don't even know how he got his job at SFU, and it's funny with the amount of dissatisfaction from the student, SFU's still keeping him. It makes me think of my university like a joke!

this guy making associate prof will mark the death of post-secondary education
what a joke of an instructor
this guy deserves to stay assistant prof for 20 years
one of the worst hires SFU has ever done, esp for graphics/vision faculty

Very bad prof who teaches the computer vision portion (roughly the first half of the semester) of the course. Midterm had a failing average and he gave us NO practice for it and didn't say any specifics of what would be on it. Overall, not a good experience taking this course so far. Do not recommend.
He is not as bad as everyone says but not good either. His teaching is so different from the exams.
my condolences if you take this course
Never seen a worse instructor. Shows zero effort to make things clear for students. Not kind either. You should avoid him at all cause. SFU needs more qualified professors.

Most accurate 1/5 I've seen. Seemed decent at first but doesn't teach anything relevant to his exam and expects you to read research papers and the two textbooks (very dense content). No sample questions, no quiz and no examples in class so you're basically going to the exam blind.

I feel like he cares about the topic a lot which is good. I don't think he deserves a one star. I wish that there were quizzes or some sort of practice tests so we had a better idea of the type of questions he would ask though. There was not a lot of connection between the textbook and test questions.

He is new to teaching and will improve.

Really hard to follow what he's talking about. He makes a simple concept very complicated. The video he provided is too short to understand. No offense I think he is a nice person but as a student who pays to study here, I think we deserve better lectures. Avoid if you can...

Concepts feel incomplete and not taught well. Yagiz doesn't provide any practice materials. It took him more than a month to release our marks. Splitting this course between vision and graphics was a really bad idea. Both topics are highly dense topics and squeezing them into one semester is not practical. Avoid if you can.
Please do not take his course. You've been warned!
You can tell he has passion for this field but he is horrible at explaining
He is a nice person but horrible at explaining concepts. Nobody in the class has any idea what's going on. I'd never take him again

The worst professor ever!! He only gave you overviews of some high level concepts. The textbook has lots of complicated formulas and he never explain how to use or test in exams. This is just an INTRODUCTION to computer vision course, not PhD course, so we are not supposed to read all the complicated papers and understand them ourselves.

It has been 3 months since the semester has started, no portion of the course has been graded thus far. Course material highly detached from examination as the material in class is very high level overview whereas the exams are heavy in math. It's been 3 months since the beginning of the semester and I have no idea how good/bad I'm doing.

He's not that bad. Honestly.
First things first, this course is mostly self taught.
Youtube videos are good quality wise. Content wise it is very good at covering high leveled topics but a bit lackluster on the low level topics.
Most of the comments here talks about his ego, but I don't see any of it so far in his course.
Midterm difficulty was ok.

Professor teaches high level basic overviews of topics. Instead of explaining them he expects you to self learn all of them. Purposefully leaves out information and then tests students on this. Does not provide any sample questions whatsoever. CAP5415 lecture playlist on YouTube will save you.

Will be an unpopular opinion here but I like the prof as a person, very passionate about the material,responsible in class and willing to answer questions. His YouTube videos explain concepts clearly and vividly and will likely pass on to future generations. However, if you want to take an easy course for credit this course is probably not for you.
the worst professor i have met ever, grade my project without reading the codes and implementing it. weird accent

He gives a good high-level overview of the topics in the lectures, and you can tell he is passionate about the topics Assignments standard difficulty Midterm and final are awful, the averages were 40%. Questions are impossible to answer with just lecture content. Don't recommend this prof unless okay with self teaching everything or bad marks.

Being in his class was high-key the worst experience that I've ever had in a class at SFU. I've never seen a professor with such an attitude and sassiness towards his students. He poorly explains his material and expects a lot from his students. No wonder why class morale is so low after his vision lectures. Avoid him if you can.

Terrible. Just don't take him. Look at the other reviews, they're 100% accurate. This guy needs to seriously reevaluate his style of teaching. Or just stop teaching altogether and focus on your research. I'd like to erase this course from my memory now. Can't believe I paid money for this.

Very rude and angry professor. Puts absolutely no effort into teaching. Yagiz Aksoy's "lectures" are only around 10-15 minutes, which does not teach me anything at all. And I have to pay full tuition for this? If you want to pursue graphics, take an online course instead. Yagiz will ruin graphics & computer vision for you.
Assignments are vague, exam was unfair as we didn't have extra time for uploading and submission. Class avg for the midterm was 39%.. He doesn't seem to care about his students. Avoid if you can!
Don't you just love a professor who doesn't explain things in detail and let you read a book that is about as confusing as his lectures are.

He provides short pre-recorded lectures on YouTube that are kinda hard to follow due to his accent. He is not very helpful on piazza either. He has strict midterm guidelines that don't make sense with the time constraint. We have to take selfies with our answers on papers and then upload each image on Coursys with no extra upload time.
Really short lectures. Really hard to understand course material. Lectures skipped important details. Had to watch free lectures from udacity. Avoid him!

One of the best profs out there.  He tries his best to help you learn what the course is about.  There was some difficult math in this course but he worked hard at making sure you understood it.  If you need help he has no problem helping you and is very encouraging.

A very nice prof. Does a pretty good job at making complex concepts easier to understand. Tries to do his best to make you do well. Exams are easy if you studied. Rather interesting assignments. NOTE: This course is not recommended for people with weak math basis.

This professor is cool! even if the content of this class was extremely easy, its assignments are somewhat fun. If you have time for them (one week of work each) you can take really high marks.
 
 He doesn't give lots of informations for the final otherwise it should be too easy to solve.. 
 Weird questions solvable thinking for 2 minutes.

Complex concepts, but the difficulty of tests was balanced. You need to understand all those concepts (hard) but once you did, you'll get reasonably good mark on tests (easy) 'cause the questions themsselves are simple (frankly I expected more chalenges and studied accordingly so maybe I feld it was easy...)
Messy notes. Strict.
The course covers a lot of content and the assignments are very long. But the prof is great, he explains things very thoroughly in the lectures. I learned a lot.
This is the COMP SCI professor not the english one, don't be tricked.  DO NOT, I REPEAT DO NOT, once again... DO NOT take this course with him.
Great Prof, start your labs early. Got EXTREMELY high mark from him

What's wrong with you stupid arts people, this is the CMPT Torsten ! OK!? Torsten is one of the worst profs in cmpt at sfu. His lecture is not informative at all, labs are brutally long and hard. His exams are hard in the sense that you never know what he's gonna test you on. It could be anything that he said in the lecture but not on the slides.
Easy tests, super long homework - helpful and easy to approach guy
Interesting course.
Good Prof, Hard Assignments, Math Intensive, Should have more code in lectures.

Good professor, easy understanding lectures, but 
TOO MUCH MATERIALS!
There are almost 100 pages slides to read every week, though the assignments and final exam were ok but still too heavy workload. You might not use all of the materials in your 4 assignments but they might be in your final exam.

Great lectures, she knows what she's doing. You'll have to self-study a lot of the math because she usually skims over it. The course is inherently difficult and covers what feels like 1.5 or 2x the material of other 300 level courses but this prof is good.

She is a good lecturer, however, I did find myself needing to go to the textbook and slides to truly understand the concepts covered. She is very fair with regards to due dates and it is obvious she cares about making sure the class is a good experience for the students. We had three assignments (cut down from 4) and a final exam.
A very fair workload and puts in the effort to lecture well. Lecture recordings were not made available.

The course was quite fun, and challenging, a good combination. The assignments always took longer than I expected, graphics are hard, so start early. They were cool though (tetris, golden bunny). She also nicely spaces them, and the lectures/notes and extra tutorial help alot.

Basically a good prof. A lot of programming and writing assignments during the semester, but she will intentionally make the final exam easy . She will organize a field trip too. Taking 3D graphics with her is not a bad choice.

I dropped this course early in the semester because of poor teaching and irrelevant therefore hard assignments.  You will have to learn openGL by yourself because the lectures only talks about concepts.  His teaching ability is poor and unorganized.  I hope there is another professor for this course since I am interested on the course subject.

This prof is a joke.  He doesn't care about what he teaches, how he teaches it, or how it is graded.  TA is always right with this prof, even when proven wrong...he just doesn't care.  Takes 2 weeks to reply to emails...only 5 people passed final!  Guaranteed F for 80% of the class, this is only CMPT class I failed in Univ.  Avoid at all cost!

No unfavorable profs are this irresponsible. Lec mostly dictionary graphic terms, interesting but totally irrelevant to asns/tests. DIY Math and Program. Unclear asn. Don't even ask he won't help.  20/22 students fail MT. Tests w/ stuff not in lec or text. And plenty of F. This isn't even a course. Only wastes your time, $, GPA, graphic interest :(

I had unfavorable profs, but none are even close to this completely irresponsible one. Lec mostly graphic terms out of the dictionary, interesting but totally irrelevant to his asns and tests. Asn outline unclear and he offers almost no help. Around 20/22 students
No Comments
TOUGH course, he teaches it as if it was 2 courses instead of 1!
a nice guy. very clear lecture. patient with every question.

Fellow student with a GPA 3.2, the rest of the class has no problem in understanding him. 3.2 is not a high GPA, I am shock you would even mentioned it as some kind of merit. Do your work, and you will be rewarded.

My GPA was 3.2 before this course, and understand I've written mostly positive reviews of profs before this guy. Herbert Tsang is just clueless. He demands formal English when he can barely speak it himself, he hasn't once given an assignment description worth damn, he doesn't answer questions by e-mail and is equally as useless in person. AVOID.

Irrelevant assignments, Use someone else's slides and randomly skips all over the place, knows nothing about programming himself, project is way off in another field. If you have interest in graphics or have plans for your GPA, then avoid him at all cost. Oh right he calls giving negative points for wrong answers on the final as "Lots of fun".

Of all the professors who've actually made me feel as if I've regretted having a class with, this guy takes the cake. We had a project, and he couldn't even explain properly what he expected out of it, he expects us to know material for the project that's not even related, and worst of all, I felt like I've learned nothing from him.

Never ever take any course taught by this stupid fool! Trust me, and I'm serious! He really knows nothing at all and his course is so boring. The only thing he can say is "You need to think about it"! If you want to try his courses yourself, best wishes and good luck!
I enjoyed the computer graphics class. Since this class is not about OpenGL, but computer graphics, I think it is OK. We are working on an interesting projects.
He's boring, the worst prof I have ever had. He knows nothing about OpenGL, and he said we should do something interesting in this course but force us to do things everybody thinks it sucks.
He will teach you what you need to know the hard way. But you will learn A LOT

Tom is a strong believer that the best way to learn how something works is by implementing it. In this course, we started with a setPixel() method, and ended it with an implementation of a 3D model renderer (subset of .obj files) and a graphics specification language for composing scenes. It was a lot of work, but was well worth it.

3 assignments, 2 week deadlines that required working 20 hours per day over both weekends. Somewhat disorganized lectures. Textbook makes no sense for the course. But, would 100% recommend. You'll learn a ton, and lectures are really entertaining. If you want to jump into coding a game, take with someone else though - very low-level concepts.
Don't take this class with him, unless you are interested in the subject. Great prof otherwise. Assignments are not easy, but FUN!
half of the class got 0 on the final (3rd) assignment

I have learned less in this course than any other because of this professor.  He enjoys leaving exams till the last minute (I think he writes them an hour or two before time).  His exams and assignments are riddled with error.
Assignments are difficult but you learn a lot from them.  Helps if you already know C++ fairly well.  Excellent lecturer... you won't want to miss them.
dun take him unless u love doing hardcore research on ur own

For some reason dude starts to tell us lecture attendance rate is so low and starts to correlate our grade against if we attend live lectures/ask questions or not. Absolutely no idea why he's telling us this. But to be honest I don't find his lectures engaging. Nice person though, but kind of stubborn.

The course itself is really hard if you are suck at linear algebra. If you do NOT have any problem with it, I would say it depends how much effort you want to put. Richard explains concept and theorem extremely clear, however for coding part especially OpenGL you have to do some research on your own. You will like this guy and this course.

Class is all theory and homework is half theory and half programming. Highly recommend you to review C++ and learn OpenGl 3.x as the homework is quite challenging and not much coding is taught in class. Exams are reasonable and straight forward.

Interesting lectures. Programming assignments were relevant and extremely fun. Plenty of room for creativity. Had to learn OpenGL outside of class, but the docs have improved a lot in recent years so this is not so much of an issue.

Lectures are all based off slides and pretty useless. But he is very intelligent and passionate at what he does.  You will need to spend lots of time coding and learning OpenGL independently.  If you are a hard worker and are able to learn things independently, you will do well.

The prof lacks the interest in teaching for the course. Always uses the same assignments.So,all the class has solns for the assignments.   Really super stupid midterm and final(totally irrelevant), feels like a high school class.  This prof really lack the skill to communicate!! Avoid this course at all cost, as you end up learning nothing!!!!

Lecture attendence range in the 30%: The correlation between class content and asn/exam material is quite literally non-existent. His notes are unusable ramblings of obscure technical terms he expects you to memorize and regurgitate. People who do attend lectures stare wide-eyed as he teaches the "obvious" and puzzles as to why nobody is there.

Richard lacks an ability to notice when people don't understand. He will throw vocabulary terms at you with minimal explanation of what is happening, and leave any ambiguities in algorithms or solutions as "an exercise". Not a math course, but memorization course. You are better off self-learning, since that's all you will do in the class anyway.

Toughest class I have ever taken in my life. Lectures are all math and concepts, while assignments are all programming OpenGL/C++. Since he does not teach programming, you are on your own. Good luck googling OpenGL. All the resources are out of date and scattered throughout the web.

Richard would be better off teaching retarded kids the alphabet. He's a really nice guy so it pains me to say this. Explanations amount to him explaining easy concepts in detail while glossing over key ones. You'll have no high-level understanding and  you'll forget EVERYTHING within minutes

I just hope he could be more helpful so that we can learn this course better. For example, when you don't even know where the "box" is, he wants you to jump out of the "box". So, I have to find the "box" first and try to get rid of the "box". You could imagine what I got finally.....
Nice guy and knows his stuff inside and out. He's an immigrant from china(?), but knows his english fairly well... yet still couldn't teach his way out of a paper bag.
First prof I've ever had that said, "I'll let you stare at this powerpoint for five minutes and figure it out yourself".  I wish it only happened once, but it seems to be his style.
This guy really makes you feel like you could fail his course, even though you probably won't. Do you enjoy 40 - 60 hour assignments? Sign up and kiss your GPA in all courses good bye.

You will learn something from good lecture notes. Programming was very demanding in assignments but seemed rewarding to finish. Midterm and Final were average-to-hard. Text was not good but everything was based on lectures anyway.
Marking is unfair
